_prev_prog_3.Description: Safety information is provided for the listed chemical (EO and SO2) as follows: (1) Material Saftey Data Sheets (2) Maximum Inventories (3) GPC's facility and processes have been engineered, designed and constructed in compliance with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices along with regulatory and voluntary industry consensus standard. These include but are not limited to OSHA PSM, NFPA, EPA, API, ASTM, ASME, and NBIC. In addition, policies and procedures are set forth in GPC Safety and PSM manual outlining both normal and emergency procedures. Copies of these manual are on file in the office of the QA/QC Manager. GPC has conducted as part of the Process Safety Management (PSM) Rule, a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of PSMcritical processes and mitigation systems to ensure the safety systems are maintained for regulated chemicals.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary





A.    Accidental Release Prevention &

Emergency Response Policies



Grain Processing Corporation (GPC II) uses every mean at its disposal to operate a safe workplace. This includes provisions of CFR 29 1910.119 OSHA PSM and 40 CFR part 68 EPA RMP. These are systematic approaches for chemical process hazards management designed to eliminate or minimize the potential for major catastrophes caused by the release of highly hazardous chemicals. GPC II will employ these measures to ensure that the means for preventing a catastrophic release, fire, or explosion are understood and to ensure the necessary preventative measures and lines of defense are installed and maintained. Every person onsite is included in these measures and management will ensure they are properly established and utilized.



B.    Stationary Source &

Regulated Substances Handled



GPC II is located in Daviess County, Indiana. The facility is a corn wet miller producing beverage and denatured alcohols, animal feed, starches, and corn syrup solids. GPC's facilities reside on 800 acres and include storage tanks and processes typical of a corn wet milling plant.



B.1    Primary Plant Operations of Concern

* Railcar and tank truck unloading areas.

* Ethylene Oxide storage and transfer systems.

* Sulfur Dioxide (Anhydrous) (SO2) unloading, storage and transfer system.



B.2    Use of Regulated Substances

Ethylene Oxide

* Used in the process to produce various starches.

* A minimum inventory of zero is handled or stored at the facility.

* A maximum inventory of 231,000 pounds (lbs) is handled or stored at the facility.

SO2

* Used in the corn steeping process.

* A minimum inventory of 16,850 lbs is handled or stored at the facility.

* A maximum inventory of 198,130 lbs is handled or stored at the facility.



C.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps at GPC II include but are not li

mited to:

* All elements of CFR 29 1910.119 (OSHA PSM)

* National Fire Protection Association (NFPA)

* EPA, American Petroleum Institute (API)

* American Society of Testing of Material (ASTM)

* National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspections (NBIC)

* American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME)



Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) for ethylene oxide and SO2 were completed as part of the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) planning. Within the completed PHAs, critical processes and mitigation systems to ensure safety systems are maintained for regulated chemicals. Policies and procedures are set forth in GPC's corporate safety and PSM manuals outlining everyday and emergency procedures. Based on the findings and recommended actions of the PHAs, changes to improve safety will be implemented as deemed necessary.



D.    Five Year Accident History



The GPC II facility has had no reportable accidents for the regulated chemicals in the previous five years.



E.    Emergency Response Program



The facility's emergency response program is coordinated with the City of Washington's Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



F.    Safety Improvements



Safety committees consisting of salaried and hourly operating personnel will evaluate and implement safety recommendations as deemed prudent. In addition, plant wide safety meetings for all GPC II personnel will be conducted on a timely basis. The Production Superintendent and the Plant Safety Director will meet on a regular basis to ensure recommendations  are being addressed in a timely and practical manner.
